worklogs.comment:
emkornfield commented on issue #5193: ARROW-6099: [Java] introduce a Logger and LoggerFactory class to remove strict dependency
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5193#issuecomment-524705920
 
 
   @zad thank you for contribution.  I don't fully understand why this is needed since slf4j is already intended to abstract logging across a variety of different logging sources.  Creating another level of indirection doesn't seem like a good idea.  I wonder maybe this could be better solved with a documentation update on how to use different loggers withing the SLF4j context?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

howryu commented on issue #5193: ARROW-6099: [Java] introduce a Logger and LoggerFactory class to remove strict dependency
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5193#issuecomment-524919036
 
 
   @emkornfield Here is our usecase. Snowflake JDBC driver plans to use ARROW library. Our JDBC jar file used to bundle all dependency so that our user does not need to include any dependency. We don't want to change this behavior, i.e. letting user to include slf4j jar file, especially if they don't use slf4j at all. Another choice for us is bundle slf4j jar file in our JDBC driver. However, in the case if our users are using slf4j and there are some conflict. With this change, our users can choose whether they want to use slf4j or not by including slf4j-api jar in their classpath or not.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

howryu commented on issue #5193: ARROW-6099: [Java] introduce a Logger and LoggerFactory class to remove strict dependency
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5193#issuecomment-524919036
 
 
   @emkornfield Here is our usecase. Snowflake JDBC driver plans to use ARROW library. Our JDBC jar file used to bundle all dependency so that our user does not need to include any dependency. We don't want to change this behavior, i.e. letting user to include slf4j jar file, especially if they don't use slf4j at all. Another choice for us is bundle slf4j jar file in our JDBC driver. However, in the case if our users are also using slf4j and there are some conflict. With this change, our users can choose whether they want to use slf4j or not by including slf4j-api jar in their classpath or not. Here is how netty used this way to avoid the situation. https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/4.1/common/src/main/java/io/netty/util/internal/logging/InternalLoggerFactory.java

jacques-n commented on issue #5193: ARROW-6099: [Java] introduce a Logger and LoggerFactory class to remove strict dependency
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5193#issuecomment-525257023
 
 
   I'm -1 on this change. It doesn't make sense to have to maintain a secondary facade. Given your situation, I suggest instead you do this the other way around: if you want to include Arrow, generate a version of Arrow that shades the slf4j dependency. You can write your own facade to the shaded APIs that can be used elsewhere. That way we don't take on new code for a very specialized use case. 
   
   In the Dremio case, we publish a version of the JDBC driver with all dependencies shaded in a private package name.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

   @emkornfield We exclude slf4j when we build our jdbc driver using shading. 
   
   @howryu Can we try and solve this using shading when building the snowflake driver?

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5193#issuecomment-525373904
 
 
   @praveenbingo So you specify slf4j as a required dependency in the pom file in Dremio JDBC driver? We tried to shade slf4j in our JDBC driver, but if our users' application is already using slf4j, there might be two slf4j library in the classpath. We encountered the issue caused by conflict.

   One way to solve this as Jacques mentioned is you can generate a build of Arrow with slf4j shaded and write a facade around that to manage dependencies.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Currently, the java library directly calls slf4j api, and there is no abstract layer. This leads to user need to install slf4j as a requirement even if we don't use slf4j at all. 

 

It is best if you can change the slf4j dependency scope to provided and log content only if slf4j jar file is provided at runtime.
fields.summary: [JAVA] Has the ability to not using slf4j logging framework

comments.body: See discussion on the PR [~jacques@dremio.com] vetoed the patch.
Closing for now, more discussion on the mailing list might be warranted and we can reopen.
Transitioning issue from Resolved to Closed to based on resolution field value.
